item.title: Working with Bibliography
item.description:
ğŸ“š What Is a Bibliography?

A bibliography is a systematic list of sources referenced by an author in their work. It plays a crucial role in academic writing, verifying the credibility of information, demonstrating depth of research, and showing respect for the contributions of other scholars.

ğŸ§  Why Is Proper Citation Important?

  • ğŸ§¾ Compliance with academic standards (GOST, APA, MLA, etc.);
  • ğŸ” Easier retrieval of referenced literature;
  • ğŸ’¡ Protection against plagiarism claims;
  • ğŸ“ Enhancing credibility and scholarly integrity.

A well-organized bibliography reflects academic discipline and respect for the research community.

ğŸ›  Tools for Managing References

ğŸ“Œ Zotero and Mendeley

These programs allow you to:

  • Save and organize references;
  • Import citations from research portals (Google Scholar, Scopus);
  • Generate bibliographies in the required format;
  • Integrate with Word and Google Docs.

ğŸ“Œ BibTeX

Used alongside LaTeX, BibTeX lets you create .bib files with source metadata and automatically format citations and reference lists.

ğŸ§¾ Types of Sources

Bibliographies can include various materials:

  • Books;
  • Journal articles;
  • Online resources;
  • Legal documents;
  • Theses, reports, and standards.

Each type has specific formatting rules.

âš™ï¸ How to Organize the Bibliography?

References can be sorted by:

  • ğŸ“… Chronology (by year);
  • ğŸ”  Alphabetical order (by authorâ€™s surname);
  • ğŸ“‘ Order of appearance in the text.

It’s important to stick to one citation style throughout the entire work.

ğŸ“Œ Conclusion

Working with bibliography is a fundamental part of academic writing. It requires precision and organization, but modern tools can help automate most of the routine. A well-structured bibliography is a hallmark of a professional and credible research effort.

item.title: Markup Languages. LaTeX
item.description:
ğŸ§¾ What Are Markup Languages?

Markup languages are systems of rules and symbols used to define the structure and formatting of text. They are widely used for creating documents, websites, and technical documentation. Unlike word processors, markup languages allow a clear separation between content and presentation.

One of the most powerful and precise markup languages is LaTeX.

âœï¸ What Is LaTeX?

LaTeX (pronounced â€œlah-techâ€) is a typesetting system for scientific and technical documents, based on the TeX language. It was designed for high-quality typography and is ideal for creating:

  • ğŸ“„ Scientific papers;
  • ğŸ“š Term papers and theses;
  • ğŸ§  Mathematical formulas;
  • ğŸ“Š Charts and tables;
  • ğŸ“ Structurally rigorous documents.

ğŸ§  Why Choose LaTeX?

ğŸ”¬ Precision and Academic Standards

LaTeX ensures consistent typography and clean formatting, especially important in academic texts. Itâ€™s the standard for many journals, conferences, and universities.

ğŸ›  Automation

  • Automatic numbering for formulas, tables, and figures;
  • Auto-generated table of contents and bibliography;
  • Built-in support for references and cross-references.

ğŸ’¡ Flexibility

LaTeX offers easy style management via templates and packages, making it a universal tool for all types of scholarly writing.

âš™ï¸ Where Is It Used?

LaTeX is widely used in:

  • Physics, mathematics, and computer science;
  • Engineering and technical fields;
  • Graduate research and academic publishing;
  • Book, report, and dissertation formatting.

Many platforms (like Overleaf, ShareLaTeX) provide user-friendly online editors for working with LaTeX without installing anything locally.

ğŸ“Œ Conclusion

LaTeX is more than just a markup language â€” it’s a powerful tool for professional document formatting. While the learning curve may seem steep at first, it pays off with precision, flexibility, and standardization. For students, graduate researchers, and academics, LaTeX is a valuable skill worth mastering.

item.title: Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment (CI/CD)
item.description:
âš™ï¸ What Is CI/CD?

CI/CD refers to a set of practices and tools that support Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment/Delivery of software. The main goal is to automate the build, test, and delivery processes â€” increasing both development speed and software quality.

ğŸ” Continuous Integration (CI)

Continuous Integration involves frequently merging code changes into the main branch of a project. Every commit automatically triggers:

  • âš’ï¸ Project build;
  • ğŸ§ª Unit and integration tests;
  • ğŸ” Code quality analysis (linting, test coverage, vulnerability scans).

The benefit: bugs are detected early, allowing teams to respond quickly and maintain stability.

ğŸš€ Continuous Delivery and Deployment (CD)

CD includes two main approaches:

  • Continuous Delivery â€” code is automatically prepared for release, but the deployment step is done manually;
  • Continuous Deployment â€” updates are automatically released into production without manual intervention.

Both methods enable:

  • ğŸ“¦ Rapid delivery of new features;
  • ğŸ”„ Stable and repeatable release cycles;
  • ğŸ“‰ Reduced deployment errors.

ğŸ§° Common Tools

CI/CD is implemented using various tools such as:

  • Jenkins, GitLab CI, GitHub Actions â€” for pipeline automation;
  • Docker, Kubernetes â€” for containerization and scalability;
  • Ansible, Terraform â€” for infrastructure as code;
  • SonarQube, Snyk â€” for code quality and security analysis.

ğŸŒ Why Businesses Need CI/CD

CI/CD helps organizations to:

  • ğŸ•’ Reduce time-to-market;
  • ğŸ’¡ Rapidly deliver new features and react to feedback;
  • ğŸ”’ Improve reliability and security;
  • ğŸ“ˆ Enhance team collaboration and workflow efficiency.

ğŸ“Œ Conclusion

CI/CD is the foundation of modern DevOps culture. It ensures a fast, reliable, and controlled development lifecycle, minimizes risk, and accelerates product delivery. Adopting CI/CD is not just a technical upgrade â€” itâ€™s a strategic move toward greater flexibility and quality in software development.

Hugo Blox Builder supports a Markdown extension for $\LaTeX$ math. You can enable this feature by toggling the math option in your config/_default/params.yaml file.

To render inline or block math, wrap your LaTeX math with {{< math >}}$...${{< /math >}} or {{< math >}}$$...$${{< /math >}}, respectively.

We wrap the LaTeX math in the Hugo Blox math shortcode to prevent Hugo rendering our math as Markdown.

$$
